content:
Here's a question that came up in my research on polarities.

Given a set LLL, let's say an LLL-labeled graph is a graph

s,t:E→V s, t: E \to Vs,t:E→V

equipped a map sending edges to elements of LLL:

ℓ:E→L \ell: E \to Lℓ:E→L

We call ℓ(e)\ell(e)ℓ(e) the label of the edge eee.

There's an obvious category LGphL\mathsf{Gph}LGph of LLL-labeled graphs, where the morphisms are graph maps that preserve the labeling of edges. And there's a forgetful functor

U:LGph→Gph U: L\mathsf{Gph} \to \mathsf{Gph} U:LGph→Gph

that forgets the labels on edges.

Question. Is this is a fibration, an opfibration, or both?
I think it's both a fibration but not an opfibration.

Maybe a good way to tackle my question is to note that LGphL\mathsf{Gph}LGph is a slice category of Gph\mathsf{Gph}Gph: an LLL-labeled graph is a graph over the graph

s,t:L→{∗} s, t : L \to \{\ast\}s,t:L→{∗}

with one vertex and one edge for each element of LLL. Let's call this graph GLG_LGL​, so

LGph≅Gph/GLL\mathsf{Gph} \cong \mathsf{Gph}/G_LLGph≅Gph/GL​

Maybe there are some theorems about when you've got a presheaf topos C\mathsf{C}C and an object c∈Cc \in \mathsf{C}c∈C then the forgetful functor

U:C/c→CU : \mathsf{C}/c \to \mathsf{C}U:C/c→C

is a fibration, or opfibration, under some conditions. But since I don't know these theorems, I would probably just go in and study whether

U:Gph/GL→GphU : \mathsf{Gph}/G_L \to \mathsf{Gph} U:Gph/GL​→Gph

is a fibration, or opfibration, "by hand". There's an obvious candidate for the desired cartesian lifts, and I think cocartesian lifts don't exist.

Maybe I am missing something, but isn't the forgetful functor C/c→C\mathsf C/c\to\mathsf CC/c→C always a discrete fibration, regardless of whether C\mathsf CC is a topos? It corresponds to the representable presheaf C(−,c)\mathsf C(-,c)C(−,c).
(But I have no idea whether the functor in question is a bifibration).
(And I'll go to bed now, so I won't be of any help at all, sorry :-) ).
Thanks! I edited some of my comments to say I think U:LGph→GphU : L\mathsf{Gph} \to \mathsf{Gph}U:LGph→Gph is not an opfibration. I was confused before.
Okay, I think I understand your argument that the forgetful functor C/c→C\mathsf{C}/c \to \mathsf{C}C/c→C is always a discrete fibration. That sounds right! Thanks.

Here's why the forgetful functor from LLL-labeled graphs to graphs can't be an opfibration. I'll show some lift we'd need doesn't exist.

Let our label set LLL be {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1}. Consider this LLL-labeled graph with 3 vertices and 2 edges:

a←0b→1c a \xleftarrow{0} b \xrightarrow{1} ca0​b1​c

Its underlying graph is

a←b→c a \leftarrow b \rightarrow ca←b→c

There's a unique map from this graph to the terminal graph, which has one vertex ∗\ast∗ and one edge. To lift this map to a map of labeled graphs, we'd need to choose a way to label that one edge. We can label that one edge with either 000 or 111, but either way there is no map from

a←0b→1c a \xleftarrow{0} b \xrightarrow{1} ca0​b1​c

to the resulting LLL-labeled graph, since 0≠10 \ne 10=1.

There is an opfibration lurking in the background: L-Gph\text{\rm{L-Gph}}L-Gph is a pullback of a much larger 2-sided fibration LabeledGph\mathrm{LabeledGph}LabeledGph living over Gph×Set\mathrm{Gph} \times \mathrm{Set}Gph×Set

Thanks! Yes, I get what you mean. In Part 2 I considered graphs with edges labeled by monoids and separately considered 'pulling back along a map of graphs' and 'pushing forward along a map of monoids' (though I didn't say 'pushing forward') there. I should be more explicit about how they're both parts of a 2-sided fibration.

All this can be done equally well using graphs with edges labeled by elements of a set, as in the thread here. The monoid is important for other reasons.

More recently, in Part 5, I discussed both the fibration @Damiano Mazza was discussing and also an opfibration that appears only when we look at finite graphs with edges labeled by a commutative monoid. The latter seems incredibly important in applications to system dynamics (which is what I'm actually studying here).
I suppose the opfibration will involve summing labels over fibers, right?

Isn't LGphL{\sf Gph}LGph the pullback

LGph→Set/L↓↓Gph→Set\begin{array}{ccc}L{\sf Gph} &\to&{\sf Set}/L \\\downarrow && \downarrow\\{\sf Gph} &\to&{\sf Set}\end{array}LGph↓Gph​→→​Set/L↓Set​

where the lower horizontal arrow sends a graph (E,_)(E,\_)(E,_) to EEE and the right vertical is the fibration sending u:X→Lu : X\to Lu:X→L to XXX? Are homomorphisms in LGphL{\sf Gph}LGph different from the ones in the pullback?

I'll answer your two questions with two questions: is an object in the pullback a graph with some edge set EEE and a map E→LE \to LE→L? Is a morphism in the pullback a map of graphs with some map on edges E→E′E \to E'E→E′ and maps E→L,E′→LE \to L, E' \to LE→L,E′→L making the resulting triangle commute?

(I think so.)

If so, this indeed my category LGphL\mathsf{Gph}LGph.

objects, yes, surely.

A morphism in "my" LGphL{\sf Gph}LGph is a graph homomorphism so that the map between sets of edges is a morphism in the slice category as well, so yes.

Then your map is a fibration (it's the pullback of the discrete fibration on the vertical right).

Right! I explained that it's a discrete fibration in Part 5 of my posts on this stuff. But I used a different argument (and I was talking to people who might know only a tiny bit of category theory, so beware).
